name: q14_9
probTex: A $C^2$ function of two real variables $u(x,y)$, defined on a region $G$, is harmonic if\n\[\frac{\partial^2u}{\partial x^2}+\frac{\partial^2u}{\partial y^2}=0\]\nProve that if $u$ is harmonic then $u$ is smooth ($C^\infty$).
solnTex: On simply connected regions, harmonic functions have harmonic conjugates. Let $z\in G$ and let $B$ be a ball around $z$ which is contained in $G$. On $B$, $u$ has a harmonic conjugate $v$ such that $f(z)=u(x,y)+iv(x,y)$ is holomorphic. Note that $f$ is only defined on $B$. However, smoothness is only a local property. Holomorphic functions are analytic and analytic functions are smooth, so $f$ is smooth. That forces $u$ to be smooth at $z$. This is true for all $z\in G$, so $u$ is smooth.
